data.text: Numb Foot when Bicycle Touring

Hey friends. I have a couple of trips planned this summer. However my feet have been going numb after 10 miles. I have pretty wide feet and clipless did t work. I have been using flats but feet still are getting numb. Any suggestions

I'd suggest going to a good bike fitter, there are many things they could identify from your riding position that we can't from a Facebook post. Sometimes numb feet could come from higher up on the body, even lower back https://www.bicycling.com/training/a20003992/numb-feet/
Numb Feet? Tingling Toes? There Are Two Main Causes of These Common Issues
bicycling.com
data.author: Jason Roussel

data.text: Yes, a professional bike fitting is needed. Although a clean bill of health should be done first.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: I have been working with a bike fitter, but no luck
data.author: Leland Johnson

data.text: Try Shimano biking sandals
data.author: Charles Nighbor

data.text: I rode with my Tevas but still experienced numbness
data.author: Leland Johnson

data.text: Than a foot doctor needed
data.author: Charles Nighbor

data.text: Sounds more like a saddle issue to me.
data.author: Dustin Schulten

data.text: how would it be a saddle issue
data.author: Leland Johnson

data.text: nerve pressure leading to circulation loss in your lower extremities.. your feet swell, shoes get tight, go numb.
data.author: Dustin Schulten

data.text:
https://www.allinahealth.org/healthysetgo/move/dont-go-numb-on-your-next-bike-ride
Don’t go numb on your next bike ride
allinahealth.org
data.author: Dustin Schulten

data.text: Ever had numb feet sitting on the toilet too long? Same kind of idea haha
data.author: Bryan Jones

data.text: agree sounds like a saddle issue.
data.author: Juston Sanders

data.text: I did recently get moloch handle bars and made my stance more aggressive
data.author: Leland Johnson

data.text: There’s your problem. It’s a bike fit issue. I had the same thing - numb toes after 30 min. Was surprising how off my fit was.
data.author: Jason Luciano

data.text: I pushed my cleats way back and that helped. I also have been playing around with raising my drop bars but also should try saddle adjustment. Play with those 3 points?
data.author: Ira Holston

data.text: I actually rode with my feet on the outside of the pedal and was pedaling with the middle of my foot and it helped
data.author: Leland Johnson

data.text:
I got my feet dialed in @ https://foothillsped.com/
Orthotics
foothillsped.com
data.author: Mark Odyssey

data.text: What pedals are you using? I have a wider foot (so does my hubby) and we run wider pedals. And since your feet swell make sure shoes are 0.5-1 size larger. Thin wool socks also (cotton is bad)
data.author: Brandi Jackson Hodges

data.text: After battling this for many years this is what (I think) I learned. 1) Most cycling socks have medium to high compression. Find thin socks with minimal compression, You’ll have to read the descriptions on the manufacturers web page to find them. Use shoes that have built in expansion in the toe box. I use Loius Garneau shoes which have the X-comfort zone thing that seems to work well.
data.author: Bob Eiserman

data.text: Be your own Lab rat. First try some cheap stretched out socks that are in your drawer with your current shoes. No cramps, done. Still cramps, move on to the shoes. Get some flat pedals from a friend and try your running shoes or hiking shoes or wingtips, whatever is comfortable. Just chip away at it with stuff you already have and you'll solve your particular issues :-)
data.author: Bob Eiserman

data.text: Did you get a bike fit? No, get one. If you've been riding for years like this sounds like you should go to the foot doctor.
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: Also as a bigger guy, this is kinda part of the package with cycling. I never got numb after 10 miles, but feet numbness was a constant issue until I lost the weight. Also try keeping your shoes a little looser if you're using clipless pedals they don't need to be tight. Shimano makes great wide fit shoes and what I wear.
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: Thanks man. I am big guy and I am thinking it is in shoes maybe even foot placement
data.author: Leland Johnson

data.text: I use Altra shoes (nice wide toebox) with cycling inserts for stiffness, and injinji toe socks. Solved my food numbness issues. But I also agree with other posts that you should look at potential saddle issues as well.
data.author: Megan Polney

data.text: For clipless shoes, check out Lake shoes. They are known for having some of the widest fits in the industry. Their fit calculator is super helpful. Also if you have a shop near by that offers bike fitting, that could also help. It's often your position on the bike that causes the numbness in the hands and feet.
data.author: Britani Rae
